published_attributes.title: üí° Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
‚ùóAll illustration related topics can be found within Illustration area space There is not only one kind of illustration, but there is also no one way of illustrator‚Äôs work

The process that we are describing is based on our Illustrator's practice and experience. Every customer for whom an illustration is created is unique - that‚Äôs why the approach to the project also has to be easily adapted to the new conditions.

published_attributes.title: üìù Know your Client - The Brief
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The Client comes to you with an idea but the Illustrator is the one who has to define it.

At the very beginning, the most important is the brief, it helps to get to know more about the Client‚Äôs business, but also it shows the illustrators the direction. The brief is the answer to the questions asked by the designer/illustrator which helps him/her to find knowledge about the following topics.

A brief word isn‚Äôt clear enough?

Do not worry! We‚Äôve got a great example, prepared by our Illustrator Katarzyna Dziadu≈õ: Brief form

published_attributes.title: üìù Know your Client - The Brief
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Brand/Company information The brand section should contain information such as the name of the company and a short description of the product or the brand itself. A style guide should be included if there is one, all of the materials that were previously made for the brand/products, the strategy and assumptions defining that particular product or brand. There should also be product characteristics, what distinguishes it and a description of who it is addressed to. It is also good to highlight the mission and vision of the company, the main assumptions. The tone of voice‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähow the brand wants to be perceived and what language it speaks to its customers. It is also good to get to know their competitors and how it communicates its values.

Tips on what the illustrator should focus on What functions it should fulfill in a product, what it should present and what values it conveys. You should also know about the implementation of the illustration, whether it is one/several images or maybe the whole system. What type of files they need to receive at the final stage (svg, png, etc.)

Technical information It is worth to find out how the illustrations will be implemented into the product and whether they should meet the criteria of the RWD website. This will tell us what size and extensions they should have. Let‚Äôs also consider whether the illustrations will be animated. It is also good to know what is the time for the implementation of the project and possible deadlines that we should meet. It is also worth considering accessibility

Moodborad This is the best tool to summarize your work with a Client, or to learn more about the style in which s/he sees their illustrations.

Illustrator Expert Call Questions üë©‚Äçüé®

The more tips and materials, the better! Here is our set of useful questions to ask at the beginning during your expert call ‚Üí Expert call questions prepared by¬†@Iryna Korshak.

published_attributes.title: üßê Exploration: Find the Style
published_attributes.serialized_body:
At this stage, we have all the information, to begin with, but remember that your communication with the Client won‚Äôt stop - asking questions are the most important part of the process at every stage of it.

  • Analyze the information and benchmarks you have collected, to be sure if you didn‚Äôt miss anything & that you have everything to start‚Ä¶
  • ...Phase of Sketches - that step will help you to quickly and easily create an outline of the illustration style and cross-check them with the client. The more feedback you‚Äôll gain on this stage, the more likely it is that the illustrations you will create in the future will be in line with the client's expectations.
  • Figure out a color palette - In most cases, illustrations will follow the brand colors, but you should always be open to explore with it or test it.

published_attributes.title: üë©‚Äçüé® Polish & Refine
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The beginning of the process is the most important here because it gives the right direction. Assuming that you have done the right briefing and that you are listening carefully to the feedback and what the client says (and I'm sure that you did!), you shouldn't have any problems finalizing the work, so‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ Once you are in line with the Client about the style, basic shapes, and color palette, you can start with:

  • Details
  • Gradients
  • Shadows
  • Lights
  • Textures

Don't forget about...

Illustrator is responsible for creating the principles of style. All elements of the style guide (or project) should be consistent, that‚Äôs why it is good to think about this from the beginning. If a style guide is not in the scope of the project - it is still worth to create documentation, where you will keep all the info about color palettes, stroke widths, corner radius, the opacity of shading, textures, etc.

published_attributes.title: üì¶ Handover
published_attributes.serialized_body:
You have to export the created illustration in appropriate files about which requirements you have already learned in the first point, in the brief part - technical information. This part is very important to make sure that illustrations will be implemented correctly.

And¬†voil√†!

published_attributes.title: üî¥ Feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
There is no one specific rule when you should ask a client for feedback, but we can advise you to ask as often as possible. You are an expert but the client is the person whose requirements must be met. Frequent and transparent communication with the customer will also help you to build trust and a good relationship that will contribute to your joint success - the outcome.

If you have got more questions or want to chat about illustration - you can find us on #pd-are-illustration¬†üé®
